channel.title: New on java
channel.description:
Hey, i just recently bought a book on java, it explains everything! i really want to learn java, because it's a very popular coding language. perhaps, if i advance with my skills i could add a contribution to the hacking/autoing scene :D
anyway, the book is very vague about wich programs i should use.. =\
i need these three things
- an editor - a compiler - a jvm (virtual machine) ((to execute bytecode))
now where do i obtain these things, please give a link or something. what do you guys use, i'm really willing to learn this :P

item.title: New on java
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

Wow, good luck on learning java, I was excited as you when I just started. Don’t worry, learning java is worth it.

NotePad is ftw, 2 features that are good with it:
-typing
-ctrl+f

that is all you need brother… and btw, is how come i just found out JDK 6 had another update??? rofl, yea dl JDK 1.6u2

Read full topic

item.title: New on java
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

He uses Textpad.

Thanks for resurrecting the dead.

Read full topic

item.title: New on java

item.description:
@Divine-Devil wrote:

Which Editor does Sean Greasley use

I need a compiler also but all this stuff is confusing!

Read full topic

item.title: New on java
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

[quote=“Krichevskoy, post:11, topic:4344”][quote author=Pwnd link=topic=5602.msg56833#msg56833 date=1151854483]
Editor: Something simple like Textpad or Editpad. I use JCreator and JBuilder.
Compiler: JDK, Java Developement Kit, comes with a compiler. Use javac *.java to compile.
JVM: Stands for Java Virtual Machine, is basically JRE.
[/quote]

JBuilder must have really improved recently or something. Seems to be the IDE of choice around here.
I use IDEA by preference, but the lab computers at school all have Eclipse, and I’m getting used to it - it does have the decided advantage of being free. I also use JCreator lite occasionally, because sometimes a full IDE just gets in the way. I don’t often quote marketing drivel, but they’re actually right:

[quote=JCreator site]
Right at your finger tips, you have all the power that you need. Other IDEs are bloated with features you’ll never use. But JCreator is faster and more efficient than most IDEs, especially Java-based editors.[/quote]

It’s also freeware.[/quote]
Ahh yes, I do love JCreator. All that power at my fingertips
Nukes Jagex headquarters

Wow…it reads minds aswel!

Read full topic

I use IDEA by preference, but the lab computers at school all have Eclipse, and I’m getting used to it - it does have the decided advantage of being free. I also use JCreator lite occasionally, because sometimes a full IDE just gets in the way. I don’t often quote marketing drivel, but they’re actually right:

item.title: New on java
item.dc:creator: @Kryptizzler Kryptizzler
item.description:
@Kryptizzler wrote:

Lewl. When you download Java, you can download jre, or jdk. I think jdk comes with jre anyways. Jre = Java Runtime Environment. Jdk = Java Development Kit? Anyways, jre is needed to run code, so it’s the vm I guess, and jdk is the compiler. Use notepad for an editor if you’re new and ffs, indent.

Read full topic
